title: Holiness and Righteousness
shortSummary: Leviticus 19 presents a comprehensive code of holiness and ethical conduct given by God to the Israelites through Moses. It emphasizes the call to be holy as God is holy, outlining commandments that govern worship, social justice, personal behavior, and community relations. This chapter highlights the importance of loving one’s neighbor, honoring God’s statutes, and living distinctively as God’s covenant people.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Exodus and the giving of the Mosaic Law at Mount Sinai

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The mediator through whom the LORD speaks and delivers the commandments to the children of Israel.

keyCharacters.name: The Children of Israel
keyCharacters.description: God’s chosen people who receive the laws and instructions to live holy lives distinct from surrounding nations.

keyCharacters.name: The Priest
keyCharacters.description: The religious leader who makes atonement for sin through offerings, as described in verses 21-22.

definitions.definition: Set apart, sacred, morally pure, reflecting God's own nature and character.
A voluntary sacrifice expressing fellowship and gratitude to God, to be eaten within a prescribed time.
The leftover crops or produce in the field after the main harvest, which were to be left for the poor and strangers.
A sacrifice made to atone for unintentional sins or violations of God’s commandments.
Holy days of rest commanded by God, symbolizing trust in Him and separation from worldly pursuits.

outline.heading: Call to Holiness and Reverence for God
outline.description: God commands Israel to be holy as He is holy, instructing them to honor their parents, keep the sabbaths, and avoid idolatry, establishing the foundation for holy living.

outline.heading: Regulations on Offerings and Social Justice
outline.description: Instructions on proper handling of peace offerings and ethical treatment of neighbors, including prohibitions against theft, falsehood, injustice, hatred, and the command to love one’s neighbor as oneself.

outline.heading: Laws on Purity and Moral Conduct
outline.description: Commands forbidding mixing species in agriculture and clothing, and regulations concerning sexual conduct and atonement for sin.

outline.heading: Guidelines for Agricultural Practices and Prohibitions on Occult
outline.description: Rules about fruit trees' fruit, prohibitions against eating blood, use of enchantments, and instructions to honor the elderly and avoid consulting mediums or wizards.

outline.heading: Justice, Compassion, and Observance of God’s Statutes
outline.description: Exhortations to respect the elderly, treat strangers with love, maintain just measurements, and faithfully observe all God’s statutes and judgments.

application: Pursue personal holiness by reflecting God’s character in daily life, honoring God’s commands and living distinctively from worldly patterns.
Practice love and justice toward others, especially neighbors and strangers, by being truthful, fair, and compassionate in all relationships.
Respect and honor authority and the elderly as part of fearing God and maintaining order within the community.
Avoid involvement with occult practices and idolatry, seeking instead to reverence God through obedience and worship.

keyVerses.text: Speak unto all the congregation of the children of Israel, and say unto them, Ye shall be holy: for I the LORD your God am holy.
keyVerses.significance: This verse establishes the central theme of the chapter—the call for God’s people to live holy lives reflecting His holiness.

keyVerses.text: Thou shalt not avenge, nor bear any grudge against the children of thy people, but thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself: I am the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This foundational command teaches the principle of love toward others, which Jesus later affirms as central to the law and the prophets.

keyVerses.text: Ye shall do no unrighteousness in judgment, in meteyard, in weight, or in measure.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes integrity and fairness in all dealings, underscoring God’s demand for justice in the community.

keyVerses.text: Therefore shall ye observe all my statutes, and all my judgments, and do them: I am the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: The concluding call to obedience reminds Israel that their covenant relationship with God requires faithful adherence to His commands.
